docs.title: Commands recap
docs.text:
• git init Initialize a git repository
  • git add <file_name> add a file to staging area
  • git commit -m "an explicit message"
  • git push origin <branch_name>
  • git branch <branch_name> create a new branch
  • git checkout <branch_name> switch to branch <branch_name>
  • git checkout -b <branch_name> create and switch to new branch <branch_name>

docs.title: Make single-purpose & small commits
docs.text: By creating small commits, it helps everyone in a team to understand what have been done. Also, it's easier to revert a small change in case of bug.

docs.title: Share only what is necessary, add .gitignore to you repository
docs.text: .gitignore list all the files and folder that must not be tracked

docs.title: .ginignore simple example :
docs.text:
__pycache__/
venv/
data/
download/
log.txt
any_file_you_want_to_exclude.any_extension

docs.title: Commit often & branch frequently
docs.text:
Prefer short-term branch, this will improve the traceability and highly simplify the code review process. Try to not include large number of change in the same branch, and avoid unrelated changes.

It's better to commit something un-perfect than nothing

docs.title: Write detailed commit message (but short !)
docs.text:
When reading a commit message, anyone should be able to understand what have been done. In general, try to explain what changed from previous code and why.

Some good examples:

  • Change led GPIO from 20 to 18
  • Fix baud-rate for SPI communication with adc
  • Change unit from miles to kilometers in compute_distance method

Some bad examples:

  • Update file1, file2
  • A modification

docs.title: Exercise
docs.text:
The goal of this exercise is to simulate a project consisting in developing a robot assistant which has many features, such as detecting persons, providing the temperature, recording cardiac frequency etc... And collaborate on its development using git. The development will be done in python for simplicity, as it's not a python lecture, feel free to create methods that only print something.

Form groups of 3 or 4 people

docs.title: 1 - Create a new git repository (locally and remotely on Github)
docs.text: You can start by adding a README.md and a .gitignore file to your empty repository

docs.title: 2 - Let's build a task tracking board
docs.text:
It can be done on github directly, which provide a very nice integration between task & branch You can choose the task management application of you choice, you just need to check that it provide an integration with github

It can be :

  • Linear
  • Asana
  • Notion (it's not dedicated to task tracking but provides a nice board feature)

docs.title: 3 - Create your backlog
docs.text:
Add the following tasks to your board :

  • 1 - Implement a basic robot that say hello
  • 2 - Create a feature to give date & time
  • 3 - Allow robots to move : right/left/forward/backward
  • 4 - Allow robots to detect obstacle
  • 5 - Allow robots to record cardiac frequency
  • 6 - Allow robots to record ambient temperature
  • 7 - Integrate some slack or discord alerts when a branch is merged on main
  • Bonus 1 Implement a more real code by adding camera / sensors class
  • Bonus 2 Create some unit tests and automate the execution

docs.title: 4 - Let's implement your robot
docs.text: You must create a branch foreach task, submit a pull request, review it with you pair and merge it Don't forget to link your pull request to the corresponding ticket

docs.title: 1 - Implement a basic robot that say hello
docs.text:
In a file robot.py

class Robot:
def __init__(self, name):
self.name = name
def say_hello(self):
print(f"hello, my name is {self.name}")

In your main.py

from robot import Robot
def start():
robot = Robot(robot="my_robot_name")
robot.say_hello()
if __name__ == '__main__':
start()

docs.title: 2 - Create a feature to give date & time
docs.text:
In your file robot.py

from datetime import datetime
class Robot:
def __init__(self, name):
self.name = name
def say_hello(self):
print(f"hello, my name is {self.name}")
@staticmethod
def give_date_and_time(self):
current_datetime = datetime.now()
print(current_datetime)

Don't forget to call the method robot.give_date_and_time() from your main.py

docs.title: 3 - It's your turn
docs.text: Now let's implement all the feature described in your backlog. As the aim is to simulate a real project (having conflicts etc...), you must develop task 3 & 4 in parallel, do the same for 5, 6 & 7

docs.title: Bonus 1
docs.text:
In a more realistic project, you will have other classes which implements some logic behind the feature added in 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 / 7. For any sensor, you'll have to configure the pins you're using in your wiring etc.

In our case, it can be something like :

  • CardiacFrequencySensor
  • TemperatureSensor
  • Camera
  • etc...
classDiagram
  CardiacFrequencySensor "1" <-- "0..1" Robot:has
  Camera "1" <-- "0..1" Robot:has

  Robot : +String name

    +int data_pin
    +int sample_frequency
    +read_value()  
  }

  class Camera {
    +int fps
    +int frame_width
    +int frame_height
    +read_frame()  
  }

docs.title: Bonus 2
docs.text:
Create a continuous integration pipeline using github action to automate test execution on pull request

Here is an example of a unit test in python: 

import unittest
from code.my_calculations import Calculations
class TestCalculations(unittest.TestCase):
def test_sum(self):
calculation = Calculations(8, 2)
self.assertEqual(calculation.get_sum(), 10, 'The sum is wrong.')
if __name__ == '__main__':
unittest.main()
